ygData.subject: Cantera Developer's Meeting
ygData.msgSnippet: I am planning to host a Cantera Developer s Meeting on Monday, April 24.  The meeting will be here at Caltech (Pasadena, CA). The motivation for this meeting

Subject: Cantera Developer's Meeting
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=44728387; y=Rzkn1W-cIXWagPIlb1R-jiKFx16tHyr9E6qRWP54qiE2
X-Yahoo-Profile: dggoodwin

I am planning to host a "Cantera Developer's Meeting" on Monday, April 
24.  The meeting will be here at Caltech (Pasadena, CA).

The motivation for this meeting is that several different organizations 
have  plans to use Cantera in large software projects, but require 
certain changes to the code before they can use it (support for other 
platforms, more templating in the C++ code, etc.).  Cantera has grown 
to the point that I no longer know of all uses, so making a change to 
satisfy one user or organization may well cause problems for others. I 
think it may be time to develop a more open procedure for proposing and 
implementing code changes.

I would like to invite everyone with a serious interest in the future 
of Cantera to participate.  I would especially welcome participation 
from:

1. The "Cantera gurus" who know the C++ code in detail (you know who 
you are)
2.  Anyone representing organizations that are or plan to be serious 
Cantera users
3. Anyone with a strong opinion on aspects of Cantera (XML, CTI, ...)
4. Anyone  who has experience managing other large, open source 
software projects


Some of the topics I want to address include:

1. What process should be used to decide on major code changes?  Would
something like the PEP (Python Enhancement Proposal) process used by
Python developers work for Cantera?

2. Should a "Cantera Software Foundation" be established? Python has a
foundation, Apache does too, and many other large open-source software
projects. This would allow transferring the copyright to the
foundation, so that hopefully people at multiple institutions could
contribute code without their lawyers getting involved.  This would
also provide a way for tax-deductible donations to be made to support a
small grants program to fund proposals to enhance Cantera, or to
develop short courses, etc.

3. Can we figure out a way to get more people involved in Cantera
development, and to take responsibility for specific parts of Cantera?
For example, I would like to find someone willing to commit to being
the "Windows guru", responsible for insuring that the latest versions
of Cantera developed on unix/Mac platforms build on Windows in Visual
Studio, and generally be the "go to" person for Windows-related issues.
  Similarly, I wouldn't mind off-loading responsibility for the MATLAB
interface either.

4. What changes do you feel are needed in Cantera?  What projects are
or will be using Cantera in your organization?


If you are interested in participating, send me an email 
(dgoodwin@...) for more information.

Dave
